Of humane in you, or a Soul that’s gentle,
You cannot chuſe but pity my loſt Youth.

speech.speaker: Maſt.
speech.line: No Stories now. —

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: Kill me direƈtly, Sir;
As you have any Goodneſs, take my Life.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Hoa! Shepherd, will you hear, Sir?

speech.speaker: Maſt.
speech.line: What bawling Rogue is that, i’th’ Devil’s Name?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: Bleſſings upon him, whatſoe’er he be!

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Good Even, my Friend; I thought, you all had been aſleep in this Country.

speech.speaker: Maſt.
speech.line: You had lied then; for you were waking, when you thought ſo.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: I thank you, Sir.

speech.speaker: Maſt.
speech.line: I pray, be cover’d; ’tis not ſo much worth, Sir.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Was that thy Boy ran crying?

speech.speaker: Maſt.
speech.line: Yes; what then?

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Why doſt thou beat him ſo?

speech.speaker: Maſt.
speech.line: To make him grow.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: A pretty Med’cine! Thou can’ſt not tell me the Way to the next Nunnery? —

speech.speaker: Maſt.
speech.line: How do you know That?—Yes, I can tell you; but the Queſtion is, whether I will or no; and, indeed, I will not. Fare you well.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: What a brute Fellow’s this! Are they all thus?
My Brother Henriquez tells me by his Letters,
The Miſtreſs of his Soul not far from hence
Hath taken Sanƈtuary: from which he prays
My Aid to bring her back.—From what Camillo
Hinted, I wear ſome Doubts.—Here ’tis appointed
That we ſhould meet; it muſt be here; ’tis ſo.
He comes.
Now, Brother, what’s this poſt-haſte Buſineſs
You hurry me about?—Some wenching Matter —

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: My Letter told you, Sir.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: ’Tis true, it tells me, that you’ve loſt a Miſtreſs
Whom your Heart bleeds for; but the Means to win her
From her cloſe Life, I take it, is not mention’d.
You’re ever in theſe Troubles. —

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: Noble Brother,
I own, I have too freely giv’n a Scope
To Youth’s intemp’rate Heat, and raſh Deſires:
But think not, that I would engage your Virtues
To any Cauſe, wherein my conſtant Heart
Attended not my Eye. ’Till now my Paſſions
Reign’d in my Blood; ne’er pierc’d into my Mind;
But I’m a Convert grown to pureſt Thoughts:
And muſt in Anguiſh ſpend my Days to come,
If I poſſeſs not her: So much I love.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: The Means? She’s in a Cloyſter, is ſhe not?
Within whoſe Walls to enter as We are,
Will never be: Few Men, but Fryars, come there;
Which We ſhall never make.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: If That would do it,
I would make Any thing.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Are you ſo hot?
I’ll ſerve him, be it but to ſave his Honour.
To feign a Corpſe—By th’Maſs, it ſhall be ſo.
We muſt pretend, we do tranſport a Body
As ’twere to’s Funeral: and coming late by,
Crave a Night’s Leave to reſt the Herſe i’th’ Convent.
That be our Courſe; for to ſuch Charity
Striƈt Zeal and Cuſtom of the Houſe give Way.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: And, opportune, a vacant Herſe paſs’d by
From Rites but new perform’d: This for a Price
We’ll hire, to put our Scheme in Aƈt. Ho! Gerald —

scene.stagedir: Enter Gerald, whom Henriquez whiſpers; then Gerald goes out.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: When we’re once lodg’d, the Means of her Conveyance,
By ſafe and ſecret Force, with Eaſe we’ll compaſs
But, Brother, know my Terms.—If that your Miſtreſs
Will to the World come back, and ſhe appear
An Objeƈt worthy in our Father’s Eye,
Wooe her, and win her; but if his Conſent
Keep not Pace with your Purpoſe —

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: Doubt it not.
I’ve look’d not with a common Eye; but choſe
A noble Virgin, who to make her ſo,
Has all the Gifts of Heav’n and Earth upon her.
If ever Woman yet could be an Angel,
She is the neareſt.

speech.speaker: Rhod.
speech.line: Well; a Lover’s Praiſe
Feaſts not a Common Ear.—Now to our Plot;
We ſhall bring Night in with Us.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Good Sir, compoſe yourſelf.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: O Leonora,
That Heav’n had made Thee ſtronger than a Woman,
How happy had I been!

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: He’s calm again:
I’ll take this Interval to work upon Him.
Theſe wild and ſolitary Places, Sir,
But feed your Pain; let better Reaſon guide you;
And quit this forlorne State, that yields no Comfort.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Ha! Hark, a Sound from Heav’n! Do you hear Nothing?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: Yes, Sir; the Touch of ſome ſweet Inſtrument:
Here’s no Inhabitant.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: No, no, the better.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: This is a ſtrange Place to hear Muſick in.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: I’m often viſited with these ſweet Airs.
The Spirit of ſome hapleſs Man that dy’d,
And left his Love hid in a faithleſs Woman,
Sure haunts theſe Mountains.
Fond Echo! forego thy light Strain,

line.emph: And heedfully hear a loſt Maid;
Go, tell the falſe Ear of the Swain
How deeply his Vows have betray’d.
Go, tell him, what Sorrows I bear;
See, yet if his Heart feel my Woe:
’Tis now he muſt heal my Deſpair,
Or Death will make Pity too ſlow.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: See, how his Soul ſtrives in him! This ſad Strain
Has ſearch’d him to the Heart.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Excellent Sorrow!
You never lov’d?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Peace; and learn to grieve then.

line.emph: Go, tell him, what Sorrows I bear;
See, yet if his Heart feel my Woe:
’Tis now he muſt heal my Deſpair,
Or Death will make Pity too ſlow.

speech.line: Is not this heav’nly?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: I never heard the Like, Sir.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: I’ll tell you, my good Friends; but pray, ſay Nothing;
I’m ſtrangely touch’d with This. The heav’nly Sound
Diﬀuſes a ſweet Peace thro’ all my Soul.
But yet I wonder, what new, ſad, Companion
Grief has brought hither to out-bid my Sorrows.
Stand oﬀ, ſtand oﬀ, ſtand oﬀ—Friends, it appears.

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: How much more grateful are theſe craggy Mountains,
And theſe wild Trees, than things of nobler Natures;
For theſe receive my Plaints, and mourn again
In many Echoes to Me. All good People
Are faln aſleep for ever. None are left,
That have the Senſe, and Touch of Tenderneſs
For Virtue’s ſake: No, ſcarce their Memory:
From whom I may expeƈt Counſel in Fears,
Eaſe to Complainings, or Redreſs of Wrongs.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: This is a moving Sorrow, but ſay nothing.

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: What Dangers have I run, and to what Inſults
Expos’d this Ruin of my ſelf? Oh! Miſchief
On that Soul-ſpotted Hind, my vicious Maſter!
Who would have thought, that ſuch poor Worms as They,
(Whoſe beſt Feed is coarſe Bread; whoſe Bev’rage, Water)
Should have ſo much rank Blood? I ſhake all over,
And bluſh to think what had become of me,
If that good Man had not reliev’d me from him.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Since ſhe is not Leonora, she is heav’nly.
When ſhe ſpeaks next, liſten as ſeriouſly,
As Women do that have their Loves at Sea,
What Wind blows ev’ry Morning. —

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: I cannot get this falſe Man’s Memory
Out of my Mind. You Maidens, that ſhall live
To hear my mournful Tale, when I am Aſhes,
Be wiſe; and to an Oath no more give Credit,
To Tears, to Vows, (falſe Both!) or any Thing
A Man ſhall promiſe, than to Clouds, that now
Bear ſuch a pleaſing Shape, and now are nothing.
For they will cozen, (if They may be cozen’d,)
The very Gods they worſhip.—Valour, Juſtice,
Diſcretion, Honeſty, and all they covet,
To make them ſeeming Saints, are but the Wiles
By which theſe Syrens lure us to Deſtruƈtion.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Do not you weep now? I could drop myſelf
Into a Fountain for her.

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: She weeps extremely.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Let her weep; ’tis well:
Her Heart will break elſe. Great Sorrows live in Tears.

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: O false Henriquez! —

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Ha!

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: And Oh, thou Fool,
Forſaken Violante! whose Belief
And childiſh Love have made Thee ſo—go, dye;
For there is nothing left Thee now to look for,
That can bring Comfort, but a quiet Grave.
There all the Miſeries I long have felt,
And Thoſe to come, ſhall ſweetly ſleep together.
Fortune may guide that falſe Henriquez hither,
To weep Repentance o’er my pale, dead Coarſe,
And cheer my wand’ring Spirit with thoſe lov’d Obſequies.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Stay, Lady, ſtay: Can it be poſſible,
That you are Violante?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: That loſt Name,
Spoken by One, that needs muſt know my Fortunes,
Has taken much Fear from me. Who are you, Sir?
For, ſure, I am that hopeleſs Violante.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: And I, as far from any earthly Comfort
That I know yet, the much-wrong’d Julio!

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: I once was thought ſo.— If the curſt Henriquez
Had Pow’r to change you to a Boy, why, Lady,
Should not that Miſchief make me any thing,
That have an equal Share in all the Miſeries
His Crimes have flung upon Us?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: Well I know it:
And pardon Me, I could not know your Virtues,
Before your Griefs. Methought, when laſt we met,
The Accent of your Voice ſtruck on my Ear
Like ſomething I had known, but Floods of Sorrow
Drown’d the Remembrance. If you’ll pleaſe to ſit,
(Since I have found a ſuﬀ’ring true Companion,)
And give me Hearing, I will tell you ſomething
Of Leonora, that may comfort you.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Bleſſing upon Thee! Henceforth, I proteſt
Never to leave Thee, if Heav’n ſay Amen.
But, ſoft! let’s ſhift our Ground, guide our ſad Steps
To ſome remoter Gloom, where, undiſturb’d,
We may compare our Woes; dwell on the Tale
Of mutual Injuries, ’till our Eyes run o’er,
And we infeƈt each other, with freſh Sorrows. —
Talk’d you of Comfort? ’Tis the Food of Fools,
And We will None on’t; but indulge Deſpair:
So, worn with Griefs, ſteal to the Cave of Death,
And in a Sigh give up our lateſt Breath.

scene.scenetitle: SCENE, The Proſpeƈt of the Mountains continued.
scene.scenelocation: SCENE, The Proſpeƈt of the Mountains continued.
scene.stagedir: Enter Roderick, Leonora veil’d, Henriquez, Attendants as Mourners.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: REST certain, Lady, Nothing ſhall betide you,
But fair, and noble Uſage. Pardon me,
That hitherto a Courſe of Violence
Has ſnatch’d you from that Seat of Contemplation
To which you gave your After-Life.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Where am I?

speech.speaker: Roder.
speech.line: Not in the Nunnery; never bluſh, nor tremble;
Your Honour has as fair a Guard, as when
Within a Cloyſter. Know then, what is done,
(Which, I preſume, you underſtand not truly,)
Has this Uſe, to preſerve the Life of One
Dying for Love of You: my Brother, and your Friend:
Under which Colour we deſir’d to reſt
Our Herſe one Night within your hallow’d Walls,
Where we ſurpriz’d you.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Are you that Lord Roderick,
So ſpoken of for Virtue, and fair Life,
And dare you loſe theſe to be Advocate
For ſuch a Brother, ſuch a ſinful Brother,
Such an unfaithful, treacherous, brutal Brother?

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: This is a fearful Charge. —

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: If you would have me
Think, you ſtill bear Reſpeƈt for Virtue’s Name;
As you would wiſh, your Daughters, thus diſtreſs’d,
Might find a Guard, proteƈt me from Henriquez;
And I am happy.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Come, Sir, make your Anſwer;
For as I have a Soul, I am aſham’d on’t.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: O Leonora, ſee! thus ſelf-condemn’d,
I throw me at your Feet, and ſue for Mercy.
If I have err’d, impute it to my Love;
The Tyrant God that bows us to his Sway,
Rebellious to the Laws of reas’ning Men;
That will not have his Votaries Aƈtions ſcann’d,
But calls it Juſtice, when we moſt obey him.
He but commanded, what your Eyes inſpir’d;
Whoſe ſacred Beams, darted into my Soul,
Have purg’d the Manſion from impure Deſires,
And kindled in my Heart a Veſtal’s Flame.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Riſe, riſe, my Lord; this well-diſſembled Paſſion
Has gain’d you nothing but a deeper Hate.
Should I imagine, he can truly love me,
That, like a Villain, murthers my Deſires?
Or ſhould I drink that Wine, and think it Cordial,
When I ſee Poyſon in’t?

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Draw this way, Lady;
I am not perfeƈt in your Story yet;
But ſee you’ve had ſome Wrongs, that want Redreſs.
Only you muſt have Patience to go with us
To yon ſmall Lodge, which meets the Sight from hence,
Where your Diſtreſs ſhall find the due Reſpeƈt:
’Till when, your Griefs ſhall govern me as much,
As Nearneſs and Aﬀeƈtion to my Brother.
Call my Attendants yours; and uſe them freely;
For as I am a Gentleman, no Pow’r,
Above your own Will, ſhall come near your Perſon.

scene.stagedir: As they are going out, Violante enters, and plucks Roderick by the Sleeve; the reſt go out.

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: Your Ear a Moment: Scorn not my tender Youth.

speech.speaker: Roder.
speech.line: Look to the Lady there.—I follow ſtrait.
What ails this Boy? Why doſt thou ſingle me?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: The due Obſervance of your noble Virtue,
Vow’d to this mourning Virgin, makes me bold
To give it more Employment.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Art not Thou
The ſurly Shepherd’s Boy, that, when I call’d
To know the Way, ran crying by me?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: Yes, Sir.
And I thank Heav’n and you for helping me.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: How did I help thee, Boy?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: I do but ſeem ſo, Sir; and am indeed
A Woman; one your Brother once has lov’d;
Or, Heav’n forgive him elſe, he ly’d extremely.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Weep not, good Maid; O this licentious Brother!
But how came you a Wand’rer on theſe Mountains?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: That, as we paſs, an’t pleaſe you, I’ll diſcover.
I will aſſure you, Sir, theſe barren Mountains
Hold many Wonders of your Brother’s making.
Here wanders hapleſs Julio, worthy Man!
Beſides himſelf with Wrongs —

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: That once again —

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: Sir, I ſaid, Julio.—Sleep weigh’d down his Eyelids,
Oppreſs’d with Watching, juſt as you approach’d us.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: O Brother! We ſhall ſound the Depths of Falſhood.
If this be true, no more but guide me to him:
I hope, a fair End will ſucceed all yet.
If it be He, by your Leave, gentle Brother,
I’ll ſee him ſerv’d firſt.—Maid, you have o’erjoy’d me.
Thou ſhalt have Right too: Make thy fair Appeal
To the good Duke, and doubt not but thy Tears
Shall be repaid with Intereſt from his Juſtice.
Lead me ’o Julio.

scene.scenetitle: SCENE II. An Apartment in the Lodge.
scene.stagedir: Enter Duke, Don Bernard, and Camillo.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Ay, then your Grace had had a Son more; He, a Daughter; and I, an Heir: But let it be as ’tis, I cannot mend it; one way or other, I ſhall rub it over, with rubbing to my Grave, and there’s an End on’t.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Our Sorrows cannot help us, Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Hang me, Sir, if I ſhed one Tear more. By Jove, I’ve wept ſo long, I’m as blind as Juſtice. When I come to ſee my Hawks (which I held a Toy next to my Son;) if they be but Houſe-high, I muſt ſtand aiming at them like a Gunner.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Why, he mourns like a Man. Don Bernard, you
Are ſtill like April, full of Show’rs and Dews:
And yet I blame you not: for I myſelf
Feel the ſelf-ſame Aﬀƈtions.—Let them go;
They’re diſobedient Children.

speech.speaker: D. Bern.
speech.line: Ay, my Lord;
Yet they may turn again.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Let them e’en have their Swing: they’re young and wanton; the next Storm we ſhall have them gallop homeward, whining as Pigs do in the Wind.

speech.speaker: D. Bern.
speech.line: Would I had my Daughter any way.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Would’ſt thou have her with Bearn, Man, tell me that?

speech.speaker: D. Bern.
speech.line: I care not, if an honeſt Father got it.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: You might have had her ſo in this good Time,
Had my Son had her: now you may go ſeek
Your Fool to ſtop a Gap with.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You ſay, that Rod’rick charg’d you here ſhould wait him:
He has o’erſlip’d the Time, at which his Letters
Of Speed requeſt that I ſhould alſo meet him.
I fear, ſome bad Event is uſher’d in
By this Delay:—How now?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: So pleaſe your Grace, —
Lord Rod’rick makes Approach.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I thank thee, Fellow,
For thy ſo timely News: Comes he alone?

speech.speaker: Gent.
speech.line: No, Sir, attended well; and in his Train
Follows a Herſe with all due Rites of Mourning.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Heav’n ſend, Henriquez live!

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: ’Tis my poor Julio. —

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: O welcome, welcome,
Welcome, good Rod’rick! Say, what News?

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Do you bring Joy or Grief, my Lord? For me,
Come what can come, I’ll live a Month or two
If the Gout pleaſe; curſe my Phyſician once more,
And then, —

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Signior, you do expreſs a manly Patience.
My noble Father, ſomething I have brought
To eaſe your Sorrows: My Endeavours have not
Been altogether barren in my Journey.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: It comes at need, Boy; but I hop’d it from thee.

scene.stagedir: Enter Leonora veilÙd, Henriquez behind, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: The Company I bring, will bear me Witneſs
The buſieſt of my Time has been employ’d
On this good Task. Don Bernard finds beneath
This Veil his Daughter: You, my Royal Father,
Behind that Lady find a wand’ring Son.
How I met with them, and how brought them hither,
More Leiſure muſt unfold.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: My Father here!
And Julio’s! O Confuſion!— Low as Earth
I bow me for your Pardon.

speech.speaker: D. Bern.
speech.line: O my Girl!
Thou bring’ſt new Life. —

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: And you, my Son, reſtore me
One Comfort here that has been miſſing long.
I hope, thy Follies thou haſt left abroad.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Ay, ay; you’ve all Comforts but I; you have ruin’d me, kill’d my poor Boy; cheated and ruin’d him; and I have no Comfort.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Be patient, Signior; Time may guide my Hand
To work you Comfort too.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: I thank your Lordſhip;
’Would Grandſire Time had been ſo kind to’ve done it;
We might have joy’d together like good Fellows.
But he’s ſo full of Buſineſs, good Old Man,
’Tis Wonder, he could do the Good he has done.

speech.speaker: D. Bern.
speech.line: Nay, Child, be comforted. Theſe Tears diſtraƈt me.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Hear your good Father, Lady.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Willingly.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: The Voice of Parents is the Voice of Gods:
For to their Children they are Heav’n’s Lieutenants:
Made Fathers, not for common Uſes meerly
Of Procreation; (Beaſts and Birds would be
As noble then as we are) but to ſteer
The wanton Freight of Youth thro’ Storms and Dangers,
Which with full Sails they bear upon: and ſtreighten
The moral Line of Life, they bend ſo often.
For Theſe are We made Fathers; and for Theſe,
May challenge Duty on our Children’s Part.
Obedience is the Sacrifice of Angels,
Whoſe Form you carry.

speech.speaker: D. Bern.
speech.line: Hear the Duke, good Wench.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: I do moſt heedfully. My gracious Lord,
Let me be ſo unmanner’d to requeſt,
He would not farther preſs me with Perſuaſions
O’th’ inſtant Hour: but have the gentle Patience
To bury this keen Suit, ’till I ſhake Hands
With my old Sorrows, —

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Why doſt look at me?
Alas! I cannot help thee.

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: And but weep
A Farewell to my murther’d Julio, —

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Bleſſing be with thy Soul, whene’er it leaves Thee!

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: For ſuch ſad Rites muſt be perform’d, my Lord,
E’er I can love again. Maids, that have lov’d,
If they be worth that noble Teſtimony,
Wear their Loves here, my Lord; here, in their Hearts;
Deep, deep within; not in their Eyes, or Accents;
Such may be ſlip’d away; or with two Tears
Waſh’d out of all Remembrance: Mine, no Phyſick,
But Time, or Death, can cure.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: You make your own Conditions, and I ſeal them
Thus on your virtuous Hand.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Well, Wench, thy Equal
Shall not be found in haſte; I give thee That:
Thou art a right one, ev’ry Inch.— Thy Father
(For, without Doubt, that Snuﬀ never begot Thee,)
Was ſome choice Fellow, ſome true Gentleman;
I give thy Mother Thanks for’t—there’s no Harm done. —
Would I were young again, and had but thee,
A good Horſe under me, and a good Sword,
And thus much for Inheritance. —

scene.stagedir: Violante oﬀers, once or twice, to ſhew herſelf, but goes back.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What Boy’s That,
Has oﬀer’d twice or thrice to break upon us?
I’ve noted him, and ſtill he falls back fearful.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: A little Boy, Sir, like a Shepherd?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Yes.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: ’Tis your Page, Brother;—One that was ſo, late.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: My Page! What Page?

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Ev’n ſo he ſays, your Page;
And more, and worſe, you ſtole him from his Friends,
And promis’d him Preferment.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: I, Preferment!

speech.speaker: Roder.
speech.line: And on ſome ſlight Occaſion let him ſlip
Here on theſe Mountains, where he had been ſtarv’d,
Had not my People found him, as we travell’d.
This was not handſome, Brother.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: You are merry.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: You’ll find it ſober Truth.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: If so, ’tis ill.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: ’Tis Fiƈtion all, Sir;—Brother, you muſt pleaſe
To look ſome other Fool to put theſe Tricks on;
They are too obvious:—Pleaſe your Grace, give Leave
T’ admit the Boy; if he know me, and ſay,
I ſtole him from his Friends, and caſt him oﬀ,
Know me no more.—Brother, pray do not wrong me.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Here is the Boy. If he deny this to you,
Then I have wrong’d you.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Hear me; What’s thy Name, Boy?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: Florio, an’t like your Grace.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: A pretty Child.
Where waſt thou born?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: On t’other Side the Mountains.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What are thy Friends?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: A Father, Sir; but poor.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: How cameſt thou hither? How, to leave thy Father?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: That noble Gentleman pleas’d once to like me,
And, not to lye, ſo much to doat upon me,
That with his Promiſes he won my Youth,
And Duty, from my Father: Him I follow’d.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: How ſay you now, Brother?

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Ay, my Lord, how ſay You?

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: As I have Life and Soul, ’tis all a Trick, Sir.
I never ſaw the Boy before.

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: O Sir,
Call not your Soul to witneſs in a Wrong:
And ’tis not noble in you, to deſpiſe
What you have made thus. If I lye, let Juſtice
Turn all her Rods upon me.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Fye, Henriquez;
There is no Trace of Cunning in this Boy.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: A good Boy!—Be not fearful: Speak thy Mind, Child.
Nature, ſure, meant thou ſhould’ſt have been a Wench;
And then’t had been no Marvel he had bobb’d thee.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Why did he put thee from him?

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: That to me
Is yet unknown, Sir; for my Faith, he could not;
I never did deceive him: for my Service,
He had no juſt Cauſe; what my Youth was able,
My Will ſtill put in Aƈt, to pleaſe my Maſter:
I cannot ſteal; therefore that can be nothing
To my Undoing: no, nor lye; my Breeding,
Tho’ it be plain, is honeſt.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Weep not, Child.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: This Lord has abuſed Men, Women, and Children already: What farther Plot he has, the Devil knows.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: If thou can’ſt bring a Witneſs of thy Wrong,
(Else it would be Injuſtice to believe thee,
He having ſworn againſt it) thou ſhalt have,
I bind it with my Honour, Satisfaƈtion
To thine own Wiſhes.

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: I deſire no more, Sir.
I have a Witneſs, and a noble one,
For Truth and Honeſty.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Go, bring him hither.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: This lying Boy will take him to his Heels,
And leave me ſlander’d.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: No; I’ll be his Voucher.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: Nay then ’tis plain, this is Confederacy.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: That he has been an Agent in your Service,
Appears from this. Here is a Letter, Brother,
(Produc’d, perforce, to give him Credit with me)
The Writing, yours; the Matter, Love; for ſo,
He says, he can explain it.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Then, belike,
A young He-bawd.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: This Forgery confounds me!

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Read it, Roderick.

recite.emph: Our Prudence ſhould now teach us to
forget, what our Indiſcretion has com-
mitted. I have already made one Step

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: Hold, Sir.—My very Words to Violante!

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Go on.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: My gracious Father, give me Pardon;
I do confeſs, I ſome ſuch Letter wrote
(The Purport all too trivial for your Ear,)
But how it reach’d this young Diſſembler’s Hands,
Is what I cannot ſolve. For on my Soul,
And by the Honours of my Birth and Houſe,
The Minion’s Face ’till now I never ſaw.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Run not too far in Debt on Proteſtation.
Why ſhould you do a Child this Wrong?

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: Go to;
Your Friendſhips paſt warrant not this Abuſe:
If you provoke me thus, I ſhall forget
What you are to me. This is a meer Praƈtice,
And Villainy to draw me into Scandal.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: No more; you are a Boy.—Here comes a Witneſs,
Shall prove you ſo: No more. —

scene.stagedir: Enter Julio, disguis’d; Violante, as a Woman.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: Another Raſcal!

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Hold: —

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: Ha!

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What’s here?

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: By all my Sins, the injur’d Violante.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Now, Sir, whoſe Practice breaks?

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Is this a Page?

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: One that has done him Service,
And he has paid her for’t; but broke his Covenant.

speech.speaker: Viol.
speech.line: My Lord, I come not now to wound your Spirit.
Your pure Aﬀection dead, which firſt betray’d me,
My Claim dye with it! Only let me not
Shrink to the Grave with Infamy upon me:
Protect my Virtue, tho’ it hurt your Faith;
And my laſt Breath ſhall ſpeak Henriquez noble.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: What a fierce Confliƈt Shame, and wounded Honour,
Raiſe in my Breaſt!—but Honour shall o’ercome. —
She looks as beauteous, and as innocent,
As when I wrong’d her.—Virtuous Violante!
Too good for me! dare you ſtill love a Man,
So faithleſs as I am?—I know you love me.
Thus, thus, and thus, I print my vow’d Repentance.
Let all Men read it here.—My gracious Father,
Forgive, and make me rich with your Conſent,
This is my Wife; no other would I chuſe,
Were ſhe a Queen.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Here’s a new Change. Bernard looks dull upon’t.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: And fair Leonora, from whoſe Virgin Arms
I forc’d my wrong’d Friend Julio, O forgive me.
Take home your holy Vows, and let him have ’em
That has deſerv’d them. O that he were here!
That I might own the Baſeneſs of my Wrong,
And purpos’d Recompence. My Violante,
You muſt again be widow’d: for I vow
A ceaſeleſs Pilgrimage, ne’er to know Joy,
’Till I can give it to the injur’d Julio.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: This almoſt melts me:—But my poor loſt Boy —

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: I’ll ſtop that Voyage, Brother.—Gentle Lady,
What think you of this honeſt Man?

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Alas!
My Thoughts, my Lord, were all employ’d within!
He has a Face makes me remember ſomething
I have thought well of; how he looks upon me!
Poor Man, he weeps.—Ha! ſtay; it cannot be —
He has his Eye, his Features, Shape, and Geſture. —
’Would, he would ſpeak.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: Leonora, —

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: Yes, ’tis He.
O Ecſtasy of Joy! —

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Now, what’s the Matter?

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: Let ’em alone; they’re almoſt ſtarv’d for Kiſſes.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Stand forty Foot oﬀ; no Man trouble ’em.
Much Good may’t do your Hearts!—What is he, Lord,
What is he?

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: A certain Son of yours.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: The Devil he is.

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: If he be the Devil, that Devil muſt call you Father.

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: By your Leave a little, ho,—Are you my Julio?

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: My Duty tells me ſo, Sir,
Still on my Knees.—But Love engroſs’d me all;
O Leonora, do I once more hold thee?

speech.speaker: Cam.
speech.line: Nay, to’t again: I will not hinder you a Kiſs,
’Tis he —

speech.speaker: Leon.
speech.line: The righteous Pow’rs at length have crown’d our Loves.
Think, Julio, from the Storm that’s now o’erblown,
Tho’ ſour Aﬀliƈtion combat Hope awhile,
When Lovers ſwear true Faith, the liſt’ning Angels
Stand on the golden Battlements of Heav’n,
And waft their Vows to the Eternal Throne.
Such were our Vows, and ſo are they repaid.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: E’en as you are, we’ll join your Hands together.
A Providence above our Pow’r rules all.
Ask him Forgiveneſs, Boy.

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: He has it, Sir:
The Fault was Love’s, not his.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: Brave, gen’rous Julio!
I knew thy Nobleneſs of old, and priz’d it,
’Till Paſſion made me blind—Once more, my Friend,
Share in a Heart, that ne’er ſhall wrong thee more.
And, Brother, —

speech.speaker: Rod.
speech.line: This Embrace cuts oﬀ Excuſes.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I muſt, in part, repair my Son’s Oﬀence:
At your beſt Leiſure, Julio, know our Court.
And, Violante, (for I know you now;)
I have a Debt to pay: Your good old Father,
Once, when I chas’d the Boar, preſerv’d my Life:
For that good Deed, and for your Virtue’s Sake,
Tho’ your Deſcent be low, call me your Father.
A Match drawn out of Honeſty, and Goodneſs,
Is Pedigree enough.—Are you all pleas’d?

speech.speaker: Camil.
speech.line: All.

speech.speaker: Henr.
speech.line: All, Sir,

speech.speaker: D. Bern.
speech.line: All, Sir,

speech.speaker: Jul.
speech.line: All.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: And I not leaſt. We’ll now return to Court:
(And that ſhort Travel, and your Loves compleated,
Shall, as I truſt, for Life reſtrain theſe Wand’rings.)
There, the Solemnity, and Grace, I’ll do
Your ſev’ral Nuptials, ſhall approve my Joy;
And make griev’d Lovers, that your Story read,
Wiſh, true Love’s Wand’rings may like yours ſucceed.
